39199686.review:
A decent little adventure/visual novel. If you don't like stories that contain sexual abuse, give it a miss. Nothing graphic, but a fair few mentions of it.

The S.P.I.N system is kinda fun, but also pretty pointless. I would of liked to see it used a lot more and more meaningfully, but it really just tracks choices so you can see which ending you are heading for. It is also a bit rediculous given the ingame mentions of the S.P.I.N system are a bit fourth-wall breaking as they are a tad ludicrous.

Despite Tokyo Dark being partly an "adventure" game there are no puzzles, just actions. If you don't like an an option given in a situation, particularly options related to using force, there is almost always another available by backtracking. If you like your video game stories to have some "game" in them, keep looking, the adventure elements attached to this visual novel barely qualify. Essentially it is a visual novel with a couple of extra elements of interactivity.

Finally the story is a pretty ordinary supernatural mystery plot. Nothing new or particularly inventive. A decent way to lose a few hours on an afternoon (apart from replays for other endings if you feel so inclined).

39163990.review: Tokyo Dark is an alternative style visual novel. It features a relatively interesting story line with multiple endings. After you complete the game once (which takes 3-5 hours), a NG+ mode becomes available which lets you replay the game with saves and skips to get to the other endings fast. The game's most appealing feature to me was how all on-screen visual elements were made dynamic to feel alive (except in Kamakura, that area looks like shit). Overall I think the game is worth getting, even (or especially?) if you're not into novels, but probably wait until it's on sale.

39034084.review:
日本の警察官が主人公のアドベンチャーゲームで、行方不明の相方を探していくうちに様々な裏社会や、サイコパス、オカルト事件に巻き込まれていき
プレーヤーの選択により先が変化していくマルチシナリオになっています。

でも、警察官と言っても日本のですからありえないでしょう？と思える場面も多々あり人によっては違和感になるかもしれません。
いきなり銃で脅すとか、アイテムを入手するために発砲するとか・・・

確かに選択しなければ良いのですが、選択肢がある事自体が気になるし、銃を使用した後の周りの反応もあっさりしているので、感情移入しづらいかなーと。
外国人が大好きな日本を舞台に作ったゲームと知った後は妙に納得してしまいましたけど。

残念なのは売りでもあるSPIN値が何に影響しているのか分かりづらく、ゲーム内で影響しているという感覚は皆無でした。
確かに攻略サイト等を見れば理解も出来ますが、逆に考えるとそこまでしないと理解出来ないという事でもあり、ゲームを楽しむでは無く
ゲームをクリアすることが目的になってしまうので、これも人を選ぶかなーと。

それにSPIN値を変動させるために選択を決めるのなら結局、選択のみで物語が進行するわけでSPIN値の重要度が薄くなってしまいますし
4つあるSPIN値の複合が選択肢の発生条件だとすると余計に物語がゆがんでいき唯の作業になってしまいます。

システムはちゃんと作られているので、もっと練りこめば良作になりそうなのがちょびっとだけ残念ですが、この雰囲気が好きな人にはお勧めです。

38950548.review:
This game is a true gem.

It's an adventure of sorts, linear, with puzzles so easy they are almost not worth mentioning. You might as well call it a visual novel, but I hate that term.

The artwork is really beautiful, as well as the amazing soundtrack. Both capture the dark neon atmosphere of Tokyo in a breathtaking way. The story is captivating, with adorable cat-pancake-scenes as well as guts-in-a-dumpster-horror-scenes, you can talk to interesting characters while struggling for mental health through all your surrealistic beyond-death-hallucinations. A bit like "Life Is Strange" meets "Detention", but a lot better that the latter and maybe even as good as the former.

It's a short ride, 6-7 hours or so, but the first game I really started again from the beginning after I played i through the first time just to see if I could decide differently and to what effect.

Thumbs up, a must-have!

38874562.review:
TL;DR: A buggy interactive graphic novel with a generic but engaging story, fantastic music and art, but not really tense, suspenseful, or bringing much new to the table.

I was a Kickstarter backer, and I backed this game because I was excited over the idea of a thriller interactive graphic novel. Unfortunately, it did not quite live up to my expectations, and I believe there are better Japanese thrillers to be played. 

Pros:
- The music! The music is fantastic. Like, truly fantastic. If the soundtrack becomes available, I might pick it up. It really does help build the atmosphere (because most of the rest of the game provides very little) in a way that really carries the narrative. The fast upbeat music is hypnotic, the slow intense music really provides a lot of tension.
- The art is very good. I wish it was a bit more animated, but in general the character models are really solid. Reina in particular is a lot of fun to look at.


Cons:
- The narrative branching and decision making is mainly saved for the last half hour of the game. There is very little in terms of decision making or puzzle solving in the hours before the end. 
- The entire story is told through dialogue, which is at times not particularly interesting.
- There are lots of bugs. Things look clickable that aren't, other things are clickable but you can't see them.
- It's a thriller, but there are very few thrills and very little tension. A few jump scares here or there, but overall very little in terms of suspense. In fact, it's almost too lighthearted at times. There are mechanics for your sanity and some other statistics, but they never once came into play for me, and it was like they never mattered at any point.

Neutral:
- The story is fairly generic for an interactive novel, but it is interesting enough to carry the game. I was at least interested in moving to the next section to figure out what was going on, and even though the resolution is somewhat bleh, the characters are engaging enough to carry the player along. 

Overall, unless you *really* like interactive novels where you have very little agency as the player, there are better games available. 
5/10

38848757.review:
This game left enough of an impression on me to write my very first Steam review, so here goes.

I'll preface this by saying, if you're looking at the store description, and screenshots, and videos, and it's even the slightest bit interesting to you, there's a good chance you'll like it. It took me a few months to finally pick this up and I really regret not buying this sooner.

I'm not going to beat around the bush. I love this game. The story is intense and interesting, the music is great, the animation fluid. Everything about this game just ticks all the right boxes for me. If you're into aesthetics and atmosphere, this game oozes with it.

As for the gameplay: It's your basic point-and-click adventure at heart. However this is mostly just a vehicle to carry the story itself. There's no pixel hunting, everything you can interact with is highlighted as soon as you near it. The "puzzles" really just amount to simple busy work or running back and forth talking to NPCs. Nothing special there.

One unique mechanic however is the introduction of the SPIN system. Depending on how you act to NPCs or treat the world around you, various stats of Ito's psyche can change postively or negatively and affect how NPCs react back to you. Paired along with this are the introduction of many choices throughout the game of how to interact with the plot. Choosing to drink at a bar, using your gun to skip some backtracking instead of looking for another solution to a puzzle, resorting to violence, all of these affect your stats in some way.

On your first playthough, the game autosaves constantly and only allows one save file, which can lead to some really intense situations. Coupled with the intense music, there were plenty of moments that really had me on edge.

Which leads me to my next point: Multiple Endings. There are quite a few different endings to get, and after your first clear of the game you unlock a New Game + mode which lets you save multiple files and skip some dialogue. (Still not all of the dialogue, and unfortunately there's still a lot to click through.)

(Addendum after second playthrough: There are actually quite a few bonus scenes and even an extra ending in NG+ so the play time isn't *quite* this short but I'll leave my first paragraph here regardless.)
Now for the one big negative I have against this: The length. At the time of writing this I have just gotten my first ending at 4.6 hours. If you care about ending hunting that's obviously not a big deal and can even be a positive but it needs to be said. Do I regret spending this much for so little? Not. At. All. I still feel this game was worth every penny, and there's still enough meat here to leave a satisfying experience.

There is so much attention to detail here and a lot of small things really add up to an awesome experience. From the animated cutscenes to the backgrounds to the story itself to the music (have I mentioned the music is great yet?), I'm going to remember this game for a long time and I REALLY hope Cherrymochi follow through with a sequel. I'll definitely be watching for it.

If you buy this, do yourself a favor. Set Discord to busy, turn off the Steam overlay, turn your lights off, put on earphones, and enjoy the ride.

38757003.review:
Tokyo Dark is a great game that I enjoyed quite a lot, and I would recommend giving it a chance even if you aren't the type to enjoy VNs. 

The story is perhaps the most important part of these types of games, and I was intrigued and on the edge of my seat from the beginning to the very end. Some scripted scenes were particularly enthralling and gave me goosebumps that few story-driven games can claim. The pacing of the story is good, and there's hardly any downtime before the next character-defining scene. The SPIN system is a cool addition and allows players to observe how their actions affect the narrative. The soundtrack is amazing and fits hauntingly well. There are plenty of endings, and some that require a New Game+, which is nice. The New Game+ also progresses the story, and isn't just another playthrough.

However, as much as I would like to gush about the game there were some shortcomings. The game isn't particularly long, and there aren't many choices that really matter. For example, I thought that being in the favor of certain characters would play a role later on in the story, but you never interact with that character again. Also, the SPIN system feels underutilized, and your parameters don't alter the course of the story all too much. Whether you play as a morally good or corrupt cop, crazy or sane, the majority of the story plays the same. All that changes is dialogue. That's a shame, because the SPIN system was what sold me on the game. Thankfully, the rest of the game is enjoyable to overcome what shortcomings it has.

Brief review: Take on SALE, if you will. Pleasant experience for the first time. Also, this game could have been just a VN.

Setting is very nice. Being detective is kinda cool. Getting to know stuff related to the case kept me invested for about 5 hours. The attention to details is steady, little things that might catch your fancy very hard can be found occasionally. It's like this game itself is an embodiment of collective subconsiousness surrounding Japanese section of mass culture. Very, very nice, if you are into the stuff.

On the sidenote, this game could have been realized as just a simple VN. Really, it doesn't bring much to the table when we are talking about mixing western PaC and Japanese VNs. It is a VN. With PaC elements. It may look point-and-click, but it is still a VN at heart. Not a mix.

Artwork is good! Music is OK! 

Story? Well, it is there. Especially the first 10-20 minutes are super rad (also the best atmosphere-inducing puzzles; if only it was true about the other parts of the game). Then it gets kinda blurry. Gameplay becomes an obligatory mess, although the setting and composition make it a worthwile experience.

Now, about replaying. It feels unnaturally prolonged. That's it.

More dark, for the gods of dark. 

Spoilers:
[spoiler]1) No save system during 1st playthrough is good. It makes your experience unique and matter that much.

If you take the first part of the game as a sole experience - it is just brilliant. Everything is there. Perfect, and going out with a BANG! But then you have to play further.
3) Did you notice the neighbour girl was gar for main heroine? It was conveyed subtly (or I just have yuri-glasses). First, she says how they were interesting neighbours, but then she keeps sweet talking main heroine, and is a little bit unresponsive on the boyfriend part. 5) Cat hype!
6) I liked two endings. Reina's and True. Others didn't feel as much.[/spoiler]

I was wrong.

The whole thing feels unprofessional. Like a product made by a bunch of 14-22 years old anime fans from Internet forums. For free. Except such game is already exist and it is much better than Tokyo Dark (Search "Everlasting Summer" or "Katawa Shoujo").

The best part of the game is a main character art.
Other characters looks horrible (imo). Especially men (reminding me of boys that forgot to shave).
The story is shallow, badly paced and not interesting.
Representation of Japan is just wrong - once again, game world is something that can be concieved by a person, frequently visiting non-Japanese Japan-related Internet forums. I don't feel that it's inspired by a rich, multilayered Japanese culture.

5/10.
Wouldn't buy again.

Nearly every session I played of Tokyo Dark made me feel stressed, paranoid, and creeped out, sometimes all at the same time.  And I loved every minute of it.

To clarify, this game is fantastic at making the player feel what the main character is feeling.  The developers have clearly put in a great deal of effort to craft an immersive gameplay experience as you follow the main character through a story that the bastard offspring of a noir dective story and a japanese supernatural thriller.  The music is creepy, the visuals are disturbing, and the story is honestly one of the best crafted portrayals of a character dealing with psychosis I have seen in a video game.

The overall game will probably only take you about four hours to play.  If for any reason you have issues with themes of suicide, forced sex, and violent murder, I'd give this game a pass.  If you are a fan of noir, Japanese supernaturalism, or psycological thrillers then I would deffinately recommend trying this game.

38018197.review:
[h1] What is this game? [/h1]
Tokyo Dark is a psychological thriller visual novel with supernatural themes and light point-and-click gameplay. The story follows detective Ito as she slowly discovers her connections to a mysterious young girl, a cursed mask and a door leading to the dark.

As the game's title suggests, Tokyo Dark is full of mature themes, including murder, corruption, suicide and abuse. This may intrugue some while putting others off.

The major highlight of Tokyo Dark is its unique "SPIN" system (Sanity, Professionalism, Investigation, Neurosis), in which gameplay choices and actions affect Ito's mental state and how characters around her perceive her. Depending on your score for each SPIN attribute, certain choices are available to you, which can lead to one of many story endings. Through this SPIN system, Tokyo Dark claims having a true "every choice matters" gameplay experience (though feel free to read my thoughts on this system in the "My Personal Opinion" section).
 
[h1] You Should [b]Buy[/b] This Game If: [/h1]
[list][*]You're looking for a more mature, psychological story-driven experience with dark themes.
[*]You're familiar with Japanese culture and are looking for an anime-style visual novel game.
[*]You're willing to invest time towards replaying the story and unlocking each ending.[/list]

[h1] You Should [b]Skip[/b] This Game If: [/h1]
[list][*]You're looking for lots of gameplay (Tokyo Dark is mostly just reading text).
[*]You're looking for more of a Point-and-Click experience rather than visual novel (P&C elements are minimal).
[*]You want a more light-hearted story experience.[/list]

[h1] My Personal Opinion (Recommendation Reflects This) [/h1]
Tokyo Dark is my second experience with the Square Enix Collective Project. I'm not very big on visual novels, though I really enjoyed the Danganronpa series and was looking for a similar thriller/mystery type game. And before I dive too deep, I'd like to say that I enjoyed Tokyo Dark as a whole, but it has it's flaws.

For having so many endings, Tokyo Dark is still extremely linear. Throughout the game, you'll come across numerous obstacles, like a locked door for example. There are almost always exactly two ways to deal with the obstacle: use brute force, or backtrack to find a specific item that avoids force. The end result, however, is really the same no matter which option you pick. The only difference is that using force or violence has a negative impact on your SPIN attributes.

So what happens if your SPIN attributes decrease? let's say you choose to shoot the lock off the door to progress, rather than find a key. This action gives Ito a sanity score of -10, which means that she becomes slightly more insane. Other than this leading to one of the potential endings, my exact sanity score seemed irrelevant to the game (and this felt true for every attribute).

Getting to the point, the SPIN system didn't seem as impactful as I thought it would be, as it was specific individual actions that determined which choices (and subsequently, which endings) I could make later on. This invalidated the importance of many micro-decisions that revolved around influencing SPIN, decentivizing me to care about these decisions.

Despite the weakness of the SPIN system, I still thoroughly enjoyed the game's linear main story and multiple branching endings. My first full playthrough took ~6 hours, with subsequent ending unlocking tacking on several more. I highly encourage players to spend time unlocking endings, as each builds upon the overall psychological theme of Tokyo Dark.

For a relatively short visual novel, I personally don't think this game is worth $18. However, if it's ever on sale, it's worth a playthrough for those interested in a short, mature, psychological visual novel.

37851743.review:
An excellent game that combines the Japanese visual novel genre with a more western adventure game feel. The result is a noir detective story that frequently strays into psychological horror territory. 

It will have you questioning reality – flashbacks, dream sequences, floating masks, and multiple endings - including an obligatory “Insanity” ending that is reminiscent of movies like Inception. At one point, while playing in a dark room, I looked away from the screen for a moment and thought I saw one of those creepy floating masks the game likes to use to mess with you. Probably more a case of bright screen + dark room = seeing weird stuff, but it fit in with the game’s creepiness factor, so I mention it here.

The game uses a points-like system to track your decision making progress, with Sanity, Professionalism, Investigation, and Neurosis meters. These can change the gameplay, from making your character respond negatively in stressful situations, to opening up new routes of investigation. Of course, the stats will also affect the game’s ending, of which there are 11.

When you finish the game for the first time, you gain access to save points and a New Game + mode that breaks the fourth wall more than a little. You also gain the option to skip large portions of dialogue, however, I’ve found it interesting how certain conversations change when comparing them to the first playthrough. My only complaint is how tedious the game becomes when you’re simply trying to click through to get to a new section or ending you hadn’t yet seen. More skipping options would have been nice – but I also think more save slots (in ng+) could eliminate some of this frustration. 

All summarized, the atmosphere of this game is fantastic – drawing you in and leaving you wondering what the hell just happened. The music and sound effects are perfect to create that sense of dread and tension. 9/10

至于其他角色，Reina也好Tanaka也好，感觉都有些操之过急，所有的行动贴近主线的终极目的，却在找人的路上没有能看见太多叙述的蛛丝马迹，支线任务应该是能好好地产生衬托主题的作用的，但这显然做的不够。
至于哲学性论述，确实没能深入下去，[spoiler]在此心疼绚美1s，忙活了大半天，本以为可以讨论一些和真相相关的事情了，可惜草草结束在了和Tanaka的会面之中。 [/spoiler]可以说秋叶原地下和书店那两场戏想办法让这个主题升华了，但很多时候需要从主角的口中讲出一些东西。或者从某种程度上说，你的思考状态会反映在行为上，遗憾的是主题的深度挖掘都交给了其他人物草草进行或是玩家的选项，实在是不够明显。

[h1] BGM& 游戏性：	[/h1]音乐很好听也很诡异，但是有点太吵了，我这种慢节奏推关的实在是嫌弃这BGM聒噪，旋律性太差了。游戏本身只有跑来跑去和选选项，在多重结局在现在看来似乎有些强行造作，但还是很值得体验，大概是讲现代悬疑还有些诡异的文字类游戏不多？其实有些希望Tokyo Dark做成流行之神的系统就是了，但一周目这种不回档选到底的节奏其实也很有趣。这毕竟是两种取舍：阅读电子小说& 增强代入感，可能什么都想做，但从剧情体验和游戏体验上讲确实是普普通通吧。

总之还是给了这个游戏推荐，希望大家不要被英文对话难倒就行，还是很值得在这些盘根错杂的选项中体验一番的，不能回档的游戏确实少见，何况悬疑、灵异、侦探这种故事最能吸引人，不是吗~

36505333.review:
As a huge fan of visual novels with attributes and choices, this tickled me to no end. I loved it a lot, to be honest.

The story was nice and easy to digest. There are multiple endings, so it's not just one of those games where it keeps track of your attributes and decisions only to leave you with one ending where none of your decisions truly mattered. I have to admit, this one of the few games where I willingly sought out the bad ends.

One thing I want to stress is that this is more of a visual novel than a mystery. There was a grand total of one puzzle and it wasn't even all that difficult and it was honestly was kind of just tossed in there. It was just a matter of making decisions, reading, and backtracking. 

Overall, Tokyo Dark was a wonderfully written visual novel with gorgeous art and decisions that matter. I highly recommend it if you enjoyed Doki Doki Literature Club and/or VA-11 Hall-A.

36502501.review:
A fantastic mystery/point and click/visual novel game which takes it's title quite seriously.

Tokyo Dark has many twists and turns with an occasional jump scare all wrapped in a blanket of creepy.  You play as the protagonist, Detective Ayami ito, who is struggling to stay sane and figure out what the heck is going on with the case her partner was working.   It starts off with a bang and doesn't let go as you dive headfirst into creepy cults and ancient artifacts dealing with the supernatural.

The visual novel portion of the game is pretty well written with themes of lost loves, morality and how much control we may or may not have over our lives.  The player must often make choices which lead down varying paths depending on how Ito reacted which also ties into the game's very creative stats system called SPIN (Sanity, Professionalism, Investigation, Neurosis).
  
- Sanity goes down as you experience horrible events and incidents but can be restored through making sure to enjoy the smaller things in life like playing with your cat.
- Professionalism depends on your demeanor on the job and how you approach people and situations.  Shoot the lock off a door or find another way in, etc.
- Investigation changes how focused Ito is during situations such as if she isn't focused enough she may not be able to notice a clue or ask a certain line of questioning.
- Neurosis deals with how often you repeat things such as walking back and forth, talking to people repeatedly etc.  Higher neurosis stat may make Ito more paranoid...

The music is fitting for every area/situation.  Heavy somber tones as you explore the darker alleyways but lighter tunes while during the day and exploring the occasional happier places.

Without giving away too much, I would say that the multiple endings are worth finding and that loose ends are almost all tied up.  Overall it was a great game that I can recommend with an 8.5/10.

36077072.review:
[h1]11月27日n周目补评[/h1]
我其实，很想改成差评……请容我稍微犹豫一下。游戏的结局很多，结局也还算精彩，通篇看下来，前因后果作为视觉小说交代的算是还可以。然而玩了3周目之后问题就出现了。一周目和二周目剧情有很大差别，[spoiler]像多数n周目套路一样，第二周目开始，很多角色包括女主自己会记得自己不是一周目了。然而二周目和三周目和n周目，除了结局之外就完全一样。简单的说就是只有初见线和非初见线。[/spoiler]游戏一周目是没有快进的，文字有些冗长，这个不多说了前文有。二周目开始，除了选项密切相关的部分，其它和一周目相同的内容可以快进，但！！！！！但是！！！！！三周目却不能快进二周目已读部分。也就是说游戏系统比橙光还要简单，只有一周目鼠标狂点系统，和二周目少数跳过多数狂点系统。为了自己多尝试几个结局，我点鼠标点的食指要断了。因为空格或者回车或者手柄人家都不认，就一定要鼠标，我也懒得为了一个游戏去更改系统设置。关于结局，除了官方想给我们看的一个结局，姑且叫它真结局之外，其他的结局都很短，在玩了几周目之后基本上可以预料，看与不看都无所谓了。游戏无尽的重复剧情和跑路让人很疲惫，能不能拿到全奖杯，要取决于我能不能找到代替我持续点击鼠标的东西。价格不算便宜，整体来说，不推荐无折扣购买，或者还是等三大妈吧。

[h1]先写在前面，我虽然选了推荐，但文字游戏确实不是所有人的菜，这款游戏文字量非常大，没有母语化的情况下对外语阅读的要求还是有的，希望大家不要因此不喜欢或者给差评。[/h1] 这个游戏对于我来说介于推荐与不推荐之间，基于还是有不少值得玩的地方，所以我还是选了推荐。个人觉得性价比一般般，建议打折时期再买。下面主要评价剧情和游戏体验。
从缺点开始说。
游戏一开篇还是比较吸引人的，对于现实和非现实的疑问也让玩家很想继续。但也同时暴露了问题：同时出场的好几个人，名字和姓混用以至于很容易分不清；游戏想要采取倒叙插叙，但过于卖弄关卡；身为文字游戏，文字相当艰涩，相当啰嗦，有种为了多写点字拖时常的感觉。不过没关系，因为我喜欢文字游戏，就也算是默默坚持下去了。坚持到一个多小时，事情开始好转，选项开始增加，剧情变化比较能够根据选择改变。这一段流程大概是我最体验最好的一段。然后就又变回来回来去说一样的话，来回来去做一样的事情，冗长的对白和毫无意义的跑路。一开始我以为配角的特点和个人故事能被挖掘出来，但怎么说，游戏对于配角的交代恰好是卡在一个说了点但又没好好说的尴尬位置，所以身为资深文字游戏玩家，既无法自己推测或想象配角的起承转合，又无法彻底当成一些npc无视之。我觉得剧本本身是希望配角的命运和主角的命运有所交互，这样让玩家的到的抉择更为艰涩，游戏性更强。然而由于这种半吊子的剧本，和相对脸谱化的角色设计，让我更多的是判断“我这次想看什么剧情”而并非真的为了角色带入思考。[spoiler]同样选择导向的游戏，行尸走肉系列、权力的游戏、暴雨杀机和超凡双生，就完全可以让很多玩家代入角色。[/spoiler]所以尽管第一天一口气玩了十个多小时，后面为了看完一周目的结局却是磨磨唧唧拖了一星期。说真的如果制作人员看到的话，我真的建议游戏流程短一点没关系，但要抓住玩家的紧张节奏。毕竟本身是没有极限脱出系列的其它类型的探索，就纯粹只是对话和选项，过分地交代废话实在是很想删游戏。期待解谜的玩家请慎重，本游戏的重点并非解谜，虽然推理的力度不是零分，但也就是1/10吧。单说推理的话，还不如很多galgame，个人意见供参考。
然后来说优点。
游戏确实有很多性格鲜明的角色，很多支线事件和细节安排也让人会心一笑。主美估计是喜欢画妹子，所以妹子们的颜值都没有太大问题，但相对汉子们就比较不忍直视。剧情本身确实围绕着一个中心，而且很多剧情选项造成的影响虽然看似很小但影响全篇剧情，这一点来说比直到黎明要优秀。所以喜欢蝴蝶效应这类剧情的可以试试，会有不少惊喜。女主的性格和能力与自身四维数值关系还是很密切的，所以在玩家不理解的情况下一周目可能会不小心做很多尝试性的错误，但这也基本符合剧情中女主本身的状态。音乐尤其是气氛bgm和效果音给游戏的剧情弥补了不少分数。剧情能否更进一步，是不是能够继续挽回文字的丢分，我想我得玩完全成就才有资格说。  [spoiler]游戏结尾的平行世界理论，和真相为何理论我还是很喜欢的，尽管放在这里有点装逼。[/spoiler]
我去玩二周目了，可能会基于游戏体验更改评价。

36005133.review:
A marriage of point and click adventures and visual novels indeed.

This game had a very good atmosphere and sense of tension whenever you had to make a decision or trekked through a dreary sewer tunnel. It does not waste any of your time, everything you do leads to more decisions and more lore behind the mystery. The visuals are also very nice, the anime style works really well with the dynamic lighting they have going on, nothing feels out of place really.

The story is also really good, mystery aplenty and some sprinkles of horror (jumpscares are the best!) but it does really tie up most, if not all, loose ends by the end of the game which is extremely satisfying. There are multiple endings which require you to run though the game a few times (new game+ systems cut down a lot of the re-runs to just a handful more). The stat system also works into the story, as different decisions and such are changed based on your stats, which plays back into the multiple endings.

But yeah! This game is short and sweet and doesn't overstay it's welcome. Massive thumbs up.

Con dispiacere, non consiglio questo gioco. Tokyo Dark è semplicemente un miscuglio mal riuscito di due generi (avventure grafiche e visual novel) che ha nella trama i classici luoghi comuni dei più noti film horror giapponesi. Il tanto acclamato sistema SPIN è molto più interessante sulla carta che nella prova dei fatti e influisce ben poco sullo svolgersi degli eventi. Il gioco inoltre risulta essere assurdamente facile e guidato, l'atmosfera del gioco (quello che dovrebbe essere il punto forte del gioco) risulta essere abbastanza piatta e con numerose cadute di stile (dico solo gatti e Yakuza). Per concludere, consigliato solo a neofiti dei due generi e con una totale ignoranza nella cinematografia horror nipponica. Per tutti gli altri, ci sono tanti giochi molto più riusciti a cui dedicare il proprio tempo.

Tokyo Dark is fusion of point&click adventure and vizual novel. 
Its dark tense story about protagonist's life turning upside down (or maybe inside out?).

The game is not perfect but it checks all the right boxes for me. 
Its mystery story, it has pretty dark vibe, protagonist is walking line between sanity and madness, it has occult leanings.
You can make plenty of choices, i didnt notice them having mutch impact on story but i only played thru twice.
Some of the choices you can make are pretty questionable, which gives game bonus points for me :)

Its horror-ish game, but it doesnt have jumpscares or gore. Its has more of mental effect, it will make you feel uneasy and tense.

I said that this is point&click adventure, its not really true. You use pointing and clicking to move your character around and to initiate actions, but all interactions are done in VN fashion. This also means protagonist's character has very limited animations. By limited i mean it can walk ... and draw gun in few scripetd scenes ... and thats all. There are few different sprites for VN segments, with different facial expresions and stuff. 

Game hase attempt at voice acting, but its limited to things like "konichiva" or "hajimemashite" when starting conversation or "kore wa", "are wa" when examining things. Thats really shame i would love to have proper voice acting for this game.

I am big fan of Innocent Grey's visual novels and while Tokyo Dark is not really close to awesomeness of Kara no Shoujo, it does pursue similiar impression and i certainly appriciete that.

Like in Kara no Shoujo, you cant achive "true ending" on first playthru. After finishing game for first time, you will get option to start "new game+" which changes things a little. Protagonist is remotely aware that she went thru all of this before, most of game stays same but some key scenes turn out differently. Its nice touch, i like it.

So final verdict. While Tokyo Dark isnt perfect, it pushes the important buttons for me and i quite like it.
Lets hope, developers will get bigger budget nextime so they can make more games like this.

35497919.review:
After putting 15 hours into the game and obtaining every ending and achievement, I have to say that I enjoyed Tokyo Dark. It's by no means a perfect game, but it's a unique and interesting take on classic point-and-click adventure titles.

Many games take place in Tokyo, but few touch upon the seedier aspects of its familiar locales. You're basically exploring the bad parts of town in this game, while following a story steeped in the occult. It's less of a police procedural, and more of a personal story about one woman's struggle with grief. The writing is consistently good and entertaining (even though you might stumble across a spelling error here and there), with a creepy, unsettling atmosphere throughout. There are no jump scares, just an ominous sense of foreboding from beginning to end. 

One thing to note is how much this game feels like a well-balanced fusion of Western and American elements. The story, the locations, the interactions, the history... all of it feels very true to the Japanese setting, draped over a framework of a game born from Western indie design sensibilities. I think the combination works very well. You get something that comes across as very authentic, yet it's darker and more uncomfortable than similar games developed solely in Japan. 

One of my biggest complaints, is that it feels like there could have been more opportunities for meaningful choice. You do a lot of reading in this game, and that's fine, but when it comes time to make a choice, much of it boils down to managing your stats, which in turn influences future choices and the endings available to you. There are only a few points in the story where it feels like the choice you've made has radically altered an otherwise fairly linear narrative. 

Secondly, this game encourages multiple playthroughs, and there are many sections that you'll have to replay over and over again. Sometimes you're given the option to skip a long dialogue, but more often than not, you'll have to click through conversations one line at a time. More "skip" buttons would be appreciated, or a "skip read" option, like the one most visual novels employ. This is only a minor nitpick though.

It's evident that a lot of care and passion went into this game. There are a handful of impressively animated sequences (not bad, considering that I've seen bigger games with bigger budgets skimp in this department), as well as a beautiful and sorrowful soundtrack. Key characters are drawn very well, with a variety of expressions and poses, though many of the secondary characters (especially male ones) are drawn with a bit less polish. It can be a bit distracting at times, but it's not a dealbreaker. 

If you're looking for an eerie story to play this Halloween, you could do much worse than a blind playthrough of Tokyo Dark. Definitely recommended.

35384511.review:
Tokyo Dark est un bon jeu. Le scénario est intéressant même s'il n'a rien de bien complexe. L'ambiance un peu opressante est bien rentranscrite visuellement et musicalement. Les différents choix n'ont pas un grand impact sur le cours du jeu (malgré les différentes fins), mais ça reste bien exploité.
En passant tous les dialogues rapidement, le jeu se finit en un peu plus d'une heure. Si vous prenez le temps de tout lire et de réfléchir à vos choix, comptez plutôt 8h de jeu (en tout cas si vous ne parlez pas anglais/japonais couramment). Si vous comptez débloquer toutes les fins, sans suivre de guide (et donc sans vraiment optimiser vos choix), comptez le double de temps.
Malgré tout, je suis un peu déçu. J'ai participé au financement sur Kickstarter et le jeu était décrit comme "a 2D point & click adventure game.". En soi, ce n'est pas faux mais Tokyo Dark n'est pas un point & click classique. Le jeu se rapproche bien plus d'une histoire visuelle interactive et je ne suis habituellement pas fan des histoires visuelles, on est trop passif à mon goût... Ceci dit, Tokyo Dark a réussi à me plaire au point de débloquer toutes les fins donc c'est simplement un petit bémol par rapport à sa présentation.

On pourra tout de même trouver quelques défauts à Tokyo Dark :
[list]
[*]quelques bugs (assez aléatoires et non systèmatique) au niveau de l'affichage des dialogues
[*]un bouton pour passer certains dialogues dans le "New Game+", j'aurais aimé que ça s'applique à tous les dialogues pour m'éviter un bon nombre de clic au moment de débloquer toutes les fins
[*]un système de choix ayant un plus grand impact sur le déroulement du jeu, ça reste assez linéaire
[*]un vrai doublage aurait été apprécié, les 2-3 mots qu'on entend n'apportent pas grand chose

35308122.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Tokyo Dark is my second review for a Square Enix Collective project (publishing platform for indie devs), after Black The Fall and I’m pleased to notice that the program hasn’t failed so far. Square has an eye for promising titles and their efforts in the publishing and promotion of such games, are commendable. Today, I’m writing about the Steam debut of Cherrymochi, a developer which also ran a successful Kickstarter campaign for Tokyo Dark in 2015, but obviously preferred to release their project after two more years of development. Time well spent, since out of my entire collection of visual novels, none has captivated me as much as this one. By opting for a (supernatural or not) detective tale, Tokyo Dark falls within my very specific criteria for the noir subgenre. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
Things couldn’t get much worse for Detective Ayami Ito. Over the course of a week, she torpedoed her promising career, witnessed the murder of her beloved partner and became a laughing stock or cause for concern, depending on who you ask about her sanity. Once a rising star of the Tokyo Metropolitan Police, she was suspended while pending enquiry into the tragic events which claimed the life of Detective Kazuki Tanaka. Right from the start, Tokyo Dark informs its players that any choice and action you take in-game is final and autosaved on the spot. There is no going back, for now. On active duty or not, Ayami sets on her own journey through Japan’s capital in search of a mysterious female killer.

I won’t spoil the plot to you, but suffice to say that appearances can be even more deceiving in Tokyo Dark than in your run-of-the-mill visual novel. Love triangles concerning scantily clad and childish characters have nothing in common with this game. Supernatural elements are quite subtle, making players question what they see or the actions based on their perception, much like Ayami herself begins to doubt her efforts in getting to the bottom of the looming enigma connecting a murderer to a certain Kabuki Mask. That object makes a persistent appearance throughout the game, from the loading screen animations and down to its implied force which drives several characters to the point of obsession. 

A surpringly light-hearted element to this murder mystery, is the prevalence of felines within Tokyo Dark. Stray cats, Cat-themed Cafés, Collectible maneki-neko figurines and even Ayami’s own house cat, all represent a beacon of calmness and hope. The protagonist’s few moments of relaxation come mostly from the interaction with her pet and several friendly faces that still believe in her crusade. The brass and powers that be, certainly won’t help make the investigation any easier, so Ito is mostly on her own while searching for her suspect, incognito and with no back-up. It’s not like the badge helped her much in the past. Perhaps it was only a hindrance.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Construct 2, a “HTML5-based 2D game editor” is powering Tokyo Dark but I admit that I am not acquainted to this particular graphics engine. The game looks great for its genre and no background or character is drawn in haste or showing any sign of asset reuse. It scaled perfectly on my monitor’s native resolution, featured no frame rate drops (stable 60fps at all times) and I encountered no glitches, bugs or crashes to desktop. A textbook example of a visual novel that takes full advantage of OS and hardware variations on the PC platform. Both Ayami and the NPCs she interacts with are well animated, from simple motions to the classic anime-style emotional expressiveness. The text speed can be sped up or skipped via mouse click.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Tokyo Dark’s soundtrack was composed by Mark Steed and I consider it beyond reproach. Most songs fit the current mood instilled by the on-screen action but I really miss voice acting when having to read so much dialogue which makes the story so gripping yet lifeless in the end. Apart from several Japanese words for “hello”, “yes”, “no” and character names, there are no spoken lines of dialogue. It’s even more baffling since complete voice acting in Japanese, was one of the first Kickstarter goals mentioned and achieved. 

I can understand not having the budget for English dubs and despite possessing a Japanese vocabulary of less than 25 words, I would have appreciated hearing the actors and actresses regardless of my personal skill in that particular language. For the record, games, movies, TV series made in Japan or with their action in Japan, are far more authentic to me if they feature Japanese dubs and English subtitles. Same applies to any country of origin as far as authenticity is concerned.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Apart from interacting with various NPCs and furthering the investigation through careful exploration of the surroundings, Detective Ito must keep a close eye on her mental well-being and her professional conduct. Something rarely seen in visual novels, we have a strong RPG element in Tokyo Dark through the implementation of the SPIN system. It stands for Sanity, Professionalism, Investigation and Neurosis. As you’d expect since we’re dealing with cases of the supernatural and Ito’s own emotional scars, some concessions shall be made in regards to her sanity, in pursuit of finding both the culprit and answers to her torment. Players will have to “juggle” with choices that can both affect and assist the protagonist at the same time.

The pills she has to ingest in order to contain her “demons”, reminded me of Detective Norman Jayden’s addiction towards Triptocaine and ironically, the Heavy Rain (PlayStation exclusive, perhaps one day on PCs & Steam) similarities with Tokyo Dark, don’t end there. Both the origami figures and Kabuki masks are inherently Japanese objects and they are integral to the plotlines from the aforementioned games. Noire themes are easy to spot, such as flawed detectives and passive law enforcement agencies which compel protagonists to take matters into their own hands, or a murder case that is far more elaborate than it appears at first glance. Sanity keeps Ayami on the right track and alive, Professionalism acts as a gauge which indicates how well she’s being perceived by most NPCs while Investigation furthers the plot and offers puzzle section hints. 

Neurosis is harder to explain but far easier to maintain within bearable limits, since interacting with Ito’s pet cat and…indulging in certain activities such as pancake eating, seem to relax our heroine quite efficiently. No inventory is implemented, but a map system with locations to (re)visit and puzzle sections, do remind us that not only RPG elements are to be found in Tokyo Dark but also features of the adventure genre. The backtracking didn’t bother me and I really appreciated the fact that you can’t attain all the game’s achievements in a single playthrough since most actions and choices lock you out of some circumstances. Having eleven endings, speaks volumes about the story’s complexity and how players can shape its outcome.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
If you want a visual novel that can skillfully mix cute and creepy in a single formula, then Tokyo Dark is your next favorite within this genre. What truly prevents a great game from becoming perfect in this case, is the severe lack of voice acting that would have fitted like a glove on this captivating adventure. I hope Cherrymochi learned a lot from their debut and I eagerly await more projects from them.

[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Intriguing storyline.
+ Beautiful graphics and soundtrack.
+ Steam Achievements & Trading Cards.
+ Replay value through multiple endings and choices.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- Lacks voice acting.

[b]Rating 85/100[/b]

[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews]Imperial Reviews[/url] and [url=https://www.ticgn.com] The Inner Circle Games Network[/url] through the generous contribution of Nick Edward.

東京を舞台としたマウスで操作するタイプのアドベンチャーゲーム。ジャンル的にはミステリー+ホラーだがそこまで怖くはない。
プレイヤーは女刑事の伊藤刑事を操作し、行方不明となった相方の田中刑事を追う。
公式日本語対応。ローカライズは実際の小説家の方が担当しており、テキストが非常に読みやすい。

ゲーム内容はパズル要素などはほぼ無く、純粋なフラグ立てアドベンチャー。新宿、歌舞伎町、秋葉原、鎌倉などを探索し進んでいく。
一応、ストアページに書かれている会話によって正気値・プロフェッショナル値・探索値・ノイローゼ値が変化し、それにより行動が変化するというシステムが組み込まれているものの、極端なルートに行かない限りはあまり関係無さそうだった。
正気値落とすと伊藤刑事がサイコ顔になってかわいい。

日本に数年暮らしているイギリス人の方が作者であり、本当に海外の方が作ったのかな？と疑うくらいに日本文化（とその闇）を詳しく描いている。
古事記や太平記からの引用から始まり、果てはアイドルの枕営業からJKビジネスの溜まり場になってしまった秋葉原まで描かれてる。マジ凄い。

特に古事記・日本神話関連がストーリーの下敷きになっており、他では中々見ない設定。また、これだけ正確な現代日本をテーマにした作品も少ないためゲーム体験としては新しく感じた。

1周3時間程度。11個のマルチエンディングで2周目からセーブポイントと真エンディングが解放される。

欠点としてUI、操作性は悪い。
マウスでの自由移動と近寄ったら表示されるクリックポイントの相性の悪さや、周回プレイ前提なのに既読スキップが完全には動作しなかったり、逆に余計にスキップしてしまったり、色々改善できる点が垣間見える。

しっかり作られた＆しっかりローカライズされたアドベンチャーゲームを遊びたい人におすすめ。

Получился очень приличный мистический триллер, в который я влип и прошел за один присест. Хотелось бы конечно, чтобы у игры был более аккуратный визуальный стиль, гораздо менее  щадящая система "морального здоровья" и не было некоторых просадок в пейсинге, но и то что есть - более чем прилично.

Отдельное спасибо за годный саундтрек.

Да, я знаю что у меня нездоровая тяга на предмет поненавидеть Девида Кейджа, но уж что поделать.

35073052.review:
Tokyo Dark by developer Cherrymochi and publisher Square Enix Collective is a detective mystery game with a focus on horror and a great storyline to accompany it. It captures the old point-and-click genre and combines it very well with anime-style visuals.

The art style used in Tokyo Dark is similar to that of a visual novel, but with much more interaction provided. The art style adds to one of the things Tokyo Dark does well, which is the game’s atmosphere. The atmosphere created through the setting throughout the game adds to its eeriness. In addition to this, the feeling of the game is enhanced by the audio and sound track during various scene changes. It captures the specific scenes perfectly and greatly adds to the overall experience while playing the game.

One of the interesting features added into Tokyo Dark is their SPIN system. SPIN stands for sanity, professionalism, investigation, and neurosis, and most decisions made in the game contribute towards one of these attributes. This system makes the player give more thought to their decisions since there are possible consequences to each decision. Morals also play a huge role in Tokyo Dark since they weigh heavily on your choices which have impact and consequences, whether that is to your SPIN stats or just your overall ending for the game. It also becomes a bit psychological when you’re making choices since you begin to wonder how exactly a simple decision can change the course of the game.

Since Tokyo Dark is a mystery and detective game, it only makes sense that it also contains puzzles. There are puzzle elements in the game that reward you or punish you depending on how well you can perform. In addition to this, some scenes have timers that require quick thinking to end up with a satisfying result.

Throughout Tokyo Dark, you are confronted with various quests that reveal more about the main story, allowing you to piece together the mystery. And since you’re in control of the character, rather than most visual novels where you are just a passenger to the story, the gameplay feels more immersive. The cut scenes in the game are also great because they add more to the scene than just a simple static image or a transition with dialogue.

Tokyo Dark does have some downsides though, such as when the game begins, you’re suddenly launched into the main story with no explanation on how to play the game and what to look for. The only feature that is explained is the autosave feature which mentions that all decisions are final. The SPIN system is also introduced and the point-and-click system is implied during the brief introduction.

One of the cons I noticed while playing Tokyo Dark is their interaction system. On the surface, it seems like a good mechanic for having multiple options for one person or item. Where it goes wrong is when there are similar options for multiple interactions, but in different places. An example of this is when you’re walking down a street and one interaction has ‘Enter’ on a door at the top of the menu, while the next one has it at the bottom or on the left. Another con about this system is that the menu is slow to appear at times, which sometimes leads to you running past them and then having to backtrack as they appear.

Another possible issue is that there is no ongoing quest screen, so you have to remember what your current goal is. This isn’t much of a problem in this game, since it keeps you on the main storyline for the entirety, but it can be a bit of a negative feature for those who speed through the dialogue while playing this style of game.

The graphics options in the game are also very limited, allowing the player to only change whether the game is windowed or full screen, brightness and contrast options, text size, language, and dynamic lighting options.

One other feature I noticed is that since Tokyo Dark is a point-and-click game, the input is limited to the mouse. At times this feels a bit limiting to the player, especially towards those who prefer the WASD or arrow key controls to move around, though there is much more control compared to standard visual novel style games.

Overall, Tokyo Dark captures a detective story fantastically, incorporating horror and anime-style themes just as well. If you’re looking for a mechanic-heavy game, this game is not for you. But if you’re looking for a mystery game with a rich storyline, puzzle elements, and a great atmosphere to accompany it, then Tokyo Dark is the game for you.

Rating: 8/10

35010874.review:
A number of story driven games love to boast that "your choices matter", but few actually deliver on that premise without sacrificing quality in telling the story. So we either have to suffer the choice of getting a bland, copy/paste, insert yourself as the protagonist story and choices you end up not caring about; or we get gripping story but you reach the end only to find out you might as well have played one with no choices at all, because all you got really was "choose ending A, B, or C" even though that doesn't fit the type of character you've been shaping for the last 40 hours (*cough* Bioware *cough*).

Tokyo Dark however whispers in your ear 2 hours in and says, "hey, remember those few silly things you did the first ten minutes of gameplay that you thought didn't matter while you were getting used to the mechanics? Those will now be haunting you and remember there is only auto-save, you casual." For that alone, this casual thanks Tokyo Dark. And with it's fascinating blend of visual novel, point & click puzzle solving (which I usually don't go for), and horror mystery with mechanics bringing back fond memories of Eternal Darkness (you yungun's ask yer folks or nerdier older sibling) this game will suck you in quick. And the multitude of endings will have you coming back for more, so the short playthrough time is a blessing if you want to see it all and still have a life. My only critiques would only be nitpicking about things others might love (I'm back and forth on the artstyle, as an example). 

Tl;dr your choices actually matter, the storytelling is gripping, and doesn't feel forced. And it has some really nifty game mechanics. So kiss Bioware and its EA overlords goodbye, and purchase this game.

P.S. Also, not sure... but I think the developers really really like cats.

34975563.review:
Сразу о самом главном: в игре присутсвуют только английский и япоснкие языки. Говорят, что перевод на русский завезут, однако, когда это произойдет - неизвестно. Так что, [b] если вы знаток английского или, не дай бог, японского, [b] а, посмотрев трейлер поиграть захотелось, [b] то своетую подождать [/b]. 

Что-то конкретное по сюжету говорить не хочу. То, про что эта игра - можно понять из тегов или того же трейлера. Поэтому, вместо того чтобы долго и нудно писать про сюжет, я лучше поделюсь [b] своим личным мнением [/b] по поводу этой новеллы. 

Что мне [b] ПОНРАВИЛОСЬ: [/b]
1) Формат. Просто сидеть, читать текст и смотреть на цветные картники - скучно. Тут же и побегать можно, кошечек по углам поискать, [strike] нажраться таблеток [/strike], и даже, припустить от страха малость можно.
2) Ачивки. Ачивок много. На каждую концовку - ачивка, на каждый выбор - ачивка[strike],  нажрался таблеток - ачивка [/strike]. Сомнительный плюс, но мне вкатило.
3) Сеттинг. У меня большой пеу на киношных детективов и нуарное кино, а в игре как раз присутствуют оба пункта.
4) Стиль. Игра действительно красивая: персонажи дышат, моргают(В 60 ФПС!!!!!!!!!), вставочки, зарисовочки - все очень стильно.


Что мне [b] НЕ ПОНРАВИЛОСЬ: [/b]
1) SPIN. Так в игре называется система, отслеживающая состояние вашего персонажа. Расшифровывается как Sanity(Вменяемость), Professionalism(Профессионализм), Investigation(Расследование) и Neurosis(Состояние ваших нервишек). Думал сначала, что система интересная, следил за своими показателями, однако, как я понял из своего прохождения и гайдиков в стиме, почти ни на что эти циферки не влияют. Вру, влияют. Если вменяемость упадет до -100, то у вас произойдет сдвиг по фазе и гейм овер, однако что там с другими я не понял. Довольно обидно, что такая интересная система делает ровным счетом ничего. Записываю в минусы.
2) Шрифт. Опять же дело вкуса, но мне шрифт показался уж больно противным для чтения. Да, я нашел в опциях кнопку "БОЛЬШЫЕ БУКВЫ", но шрифт от этого не поменялся.
3) Линейность. Как ни странно, но игра оказалась очень линейной. Причина вся в том, что какие-либо ответвления появляются только в самом конце игры. В остальном, игра будет всегда одинаковой, все зависимости от ваших чузов. Какой бы выбор вы не сделали, все равно будет так, как заложено в скрипте. То есть даже если вы выбрали опцию ОТКАЗАТЬ В ПОМОЩИ, помогать все равно придется: поменяется только диалог с персонажем, да и то не весь.
4) Предсказуемость. Все персонажи в игре ведут себя до омерзения предсказуемо. Задания, которые эти люди дают, следовательно, тоже. Почти вся игра состоит из завязок по типу: вам нужно что-то, это что-то есть у кого-то, этот кто-то говорит вам сделать что-то и только тогда-то этот кто-то даст вам что-то. Как-то так.

Последую общим трендам и поставлю игре следующие оценки(кого это вообще интересует):
[b]
КАРТИНКА - 10/10
ЗВУК - 8/10
СЮЖЕТ - 6/10
ГЕЙМПЛЕЙ - 2/10(по меркам игры-адвенчуры, а не новеллы)
НАЛИЧИЕ РУССКОГО ЯЗЫКА - 0/10
ОБЩЕЕ - 6.5/10
[/b]
----------------------------------------
Если вы играете в визуальные новеллы ради откровенных сцен в конце - НЕ СТОИТ ПОКУПАТЬ 
Если у вас пеу на нуарные детективы - СТОИТ ПОКУПАТЬ
Если ваш словарный запас английского +-200 слов - НЕ СТОИТ ПОКУПАТЬ
Если вы любите кошечек - ПОКУПАЙТЕ ИГРУ
все.

34966027.review:
This is definitely a game for those who enjoy the visual novel genre, but if your willing to take a chance with it, this game does have a lot of unique features that seperate it from many others. 

Probably the most noticeable feature is that your choices truly do matter in this game, and the way they do that is not only simple but rather ingeneous: After making a decision (like say shooting at a lock instead of finding a hairpin to pick at it), the game will autosave, meaning that if you want to redo that decision again, you'll need to start the entire game over from the beginning. 

The story, while not very memorable in my opinion (though it's probably because I only stopped after getting one ending), does have a unique array of characters that help compliment the game, helping you unravel the seedy underbelly of the Tokyo nightlife. It'll keep you engaged if your a fan of crime and psychological horror stories. 

The artistic style is not bad as well; it really captures the Tokyo nightlife: Showing the cheerful facade that we associate with the city, while exposing the nasty underbelly with very earthly colors and rushed paint strokes. And finally there is the music, which, personally, really does sell the game: It gives you the pinging sense of dread that something is off.

Update: Nominated it for the Choices Matter Award

34954748.review:
Very good, if somewhat short game, in the mould of Broken Sword, but with more horror, less humour and at best, melocholy endings - don't expect anything light and fluffy here - it's not afraid to show seedy sides to Tokyo and surrounding areas.

In-game graphics are very nice, especially the movement of Ito.  The short animated cut-scenese are typical Japanese animation - not exactly my taste - but they do work.

There is only one "tricky" puzzle to solve, the rest is just working out what to do next.

The characters you meet all have different personailitys and by the end, you'll find out what happened to a few of them, mainly due to your (in)actions - don't expect everything to be happy though!

Music is atmospheric and fits in well.

Overall, well worth getting, especially if its on sale.

34947335.review:
I spit non-spoiled review into two section (English and Thai language)
การรีวิวไม่สปอยล์นี้แบ่งออกเป็นสองภาษา (อังกฤษ – ไทย)

---------------[English]---------------

Tokyo Dark is side-scrolling adventure game developed by Cheerymochi in 2015 Kickstarter project. The game represents combination of story-driven visual novel style and choice-based element, setting in deep dark corners of Tokyo.

You play as detective Ayami Ito, searching for her missing partner, and uncover the truth of Tokyo urban legend. The story pacing is well done, intrigues player with clear goal, but tricks you with psychological elements. The dialogues are well-written and natural; some are related to philosophy and mythology as supporting elements.

The art style is totally optional; it is what I expect from Kickstarter. Each scene has own quality soundtrack that capture the feeling and atmosphere expect very few unpolished background. The game also includes few animated sequence from Graphinica (Production Company behind series such as Hellsing, Long Live!), which it might be reason of release price.

In term of gameplay, you progress the story by searching clues in area and asking various NPCs for information. Gathering information sometimes requires puzzle solving, but it is not particular hard and allows multiple approaches.

Ito’s mental state represents in S.P.I.N features (Sanity, Professionalism, Investigation, and Neurosis). Most of every decision does matter, it has own consequence that affect some of her S.P.I.N stats which can lead to her different perspective, choice, and endings. It reminds me old mechanics from various crime games and well implement into VN style.

However, I feel like S.P.I.N system is easily manageable and doesn’t emphasize player awareness due to less punishment. The game design introduces the importance of choice by disable save-load system on your first playthrough and enables broken memory features to let players experience different choices. It’s quite smart design that supports repeatability although there are only six slots. The game also has startup issues and game-breaking bug on release which they are fixed in latest patch, but still remain some UI display issues.

Overall, Tokyo Dark is quite short experience (4-6 hours for first playthrough), but fill with interesting gameplay, well-written psychological storyline, and strong dark atmosphere. If you interest in this kind of genre, Tokyo Dark is great choice to try.  


---------------[ภาษาไทย]---------------

Tokyo Dark เป็นเกมแนวผจญภัยมุมมองด้านข้างพัฒนาโดยสตูดิโอ Cheerymochi จากโปรเจคระดมทุนปี 2015 ตัวเกมนำเสนอส่วนผสมระหว่างนิยายภาพและระบบตัวเลือกท่ามกลางบรรยาากศอันดำมืดของมหานครโตเกียว

คุณจะได้สวมบทบาทเป็นนักสืบ อายามิ อิโตะ ออกตามหาคู่หูของเธอซึ่งหายตัวไป และเปิดเผยความจริงของตำนานเมือง Tokyo Dark มีจังหวะการดำเนินเรื่องที่ดี ชัดเจน แต่แทรกลูกเล่นเชิงจิตวิทยาในระหว่างการดำเนินเรื่อง บทสนทนาระหว่างตัวละครที่เขียนออกมาเป็นธรรมชาติ หลากอารมรณ์ตั้งแต่ จริงจัง ชวนขบขัน ความรู้สึกภายในของตัวละครนั้นๆ บางครั้งยังแฝงไปด้วยหลักปรัชญาของชีวิตและตำนานปรัมปราที่เสริมน้ำหนักของเรื่องราว

ในส่วนของงานศิลป์ตัวละครและพื้นหลังมีคุณภาพ แม้ว่าจะมีบางส่วนของพื้นหลังที่ดูแข็งทื่อไปบ้าง แต่ล่ะฉากมีเอฟเฟกต์และเพลงประกอบเสริมบรรยากาศออกมาได้อย่างน่าประทับใจ รวมทั้งฉากอนิเมชั่นจากบริษัท Graphinica (มีผลงานเบื้องหลังอนิเมะชื่อดังอย่าง Hellsing, Long Live!) และอาจเป็นเหตุผลของราคาตัวเกมที่สูงกว่าปกติ

Tokyo Dark มีระบบการเล่นที่เรียบง่าย ผู้เล่นดำเนินเรื่องผ่านการรวบรวมเบาะแสภายในฉากและการปฏิสัมพันธ์กับ NPC ข้อมูลสำคัญบางจุดจะผ่านการแก้ปริศนา โดยตัวละครสื่อวิธีออกมาเป็นนัย และบางปริศนาสามารถแก้ด้วยหลากวิธี

นอกจากนั้นอีโตะยังมีสถานะของสภาพจิตใจที่เรียกว่า S.P.I.N (ขับเคลื่อนด้วยตัวแปร 4 ประการ ภาวะจิต, ความเป็นมืออาชีพ, การสืบสวน, สภาพประสาท) เกือบทุกๆ การกระทำของผู้เล่นจะส่งผลถึงค่าต่างๆ มากน้อยตามสถานการณ์ และยังส่งผลถึงฉากจบของเรื่องราว ระบบดังกล่าวเป็นกลไลที่เคยใช้ในเกมแนวสืบสวน และ Tokyo Dark ก็สามารถปรับใช้ให้เข้ากับธีมของตัวเกมได้อย่างดี

อย่างไรก็ตาม ระบบ S.P.I.N ค่อนข้างจัดการได้ง่าย แม้ว่าจะมีบางสถาณการณ์ที่ไม่สามารถหลีกเลี่ยงการเปลี่ยนแปลงค่าได้ ค่า S.P.I.N ควรมีผลในเชิงรูปธรรมปัจจุบันนี้ มากกว่าเป็นเพียงตัวแปรที่ส่งผลต่อฉากจบหรือบางบทสนทนา ตัวเกมยังไม่อนุญาตให้มีการใช้ระบบรีโหลด-เซฟเหมือนนิยายภาพทั่วไปในการเล่นครั้งแรก ผมมองว่าเป็นการออกแบบที่สอนให้ผู้เล่นรู้จักความสำคัญของแต่ล่ะการกระทำ และเรียกร้องการเล่นซ้ำสูงเพื่อค้นพบฉากจบทั้ง 11 แบบ ในเวลาเดียวกัน ผู้เล่นบางท่านอาจจะรู้สึกถูกบังคับและจำนวนเซฟสล็อตที่มีเพียง 6 ช่องอาจจะไม่เพียงพอที่จะครอบคลุมทุกฉากจบ ตัวเกมมีปัญหาทางเทคนิคในการจำหน่ายวันแรก เช่น ปัญหาการเริ่มเกม และบัคที่ไม่สามารถดำเนินเรื่องต่อได้ ซึ่งต่อมาได้รับการแก้ไขแต่ก็ยังมีปัญหาด้าน UI เล็กน้อย เช่น การแสดงผล ไอคอนที่กลืนกับฉากพื้นหลังเป็นต้น

แม้จะมีปัญหาบางส่วนและระบบที่สามารถแสดงศักยภาพได้มากกว่านี้ Tokyo Dark กลับมอบประสบการณ์อันน่าประทับใจ (ใช้เวลาเฉลี่ย 4-6 ชั่วโมงในการเล่นครั้งแรก) ด้วยส่วนผสมการเล่นอันลงตัว เรื่องราวชวนติดตาม และการนำเสนอบรรยากาศโตเกียวในอีกแง่มุม หากคุณเป็นคนที่หลงใหลแนวสืบสวนลึกลับเชิงจิตวิทยา Tokyo Dark เป็นหนึ่งในตัวเลือกที่คุณไม่ควรพลาด

Da Sidescrolling Adventure eigentlich nicht zu meinen favorisierten Genres gehören, war ich anfangs sehr skeptisch, ob ich das Spiel tatsächlich bis zum Ende spielen werde.
Jedoch ist die Geschichte rund um Detektivin Ito und dem Verschwinden ihres Partners sehr fesselnd und motiviert stetig, weiter zu spielen.
Die 11 möglichen Enden, die verschiedenen Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten sowie deren Auswirkungen auf die geistige Gesundheit der Protagonistin wirken größtenteils ausgefeilt und geben dem Spieler das Gefühl, tatsächlichen Einfluss auf den Verlauf der Geschichte zu haben.
Die Grafik und die musikalische Untermalung sind schön gelungen und passen zu den einzelnen Orten und Handlungssträngen der Geschichte.
Einzig einige wenige Bugs und das doch gewöhnungsbedürftige Menü fallen negativ auf.

Fazit: Ein Sidescroller mit einer schönen, düsteren Geschichte, einer passenden Grafik im Anime Stil, den es sich lohnt wieder erneut zu spielen.

34916186.review:
在游戏中讲一个好故事——这可是越来越难了。很多游戏画面精美绝伦，多边形堆得数不胜数，然而通关以后回想起剧情，玩家才发现这“故事”实在是单薄的可怜：正派和反派都是箭垛式的人物，所谓的“人物驱动”仔细推敲起来也是幼稚的可怕。

自从2015年的“Life is Strange”之后，我还没能玩到一个同样像Tokyo Dark这样令人惊喜的游戏。而事实上，就连LIS的第四、五章也有令人遗憾的部分。像Cherrymochi这样的独立制作公司，能把开篇时的剧情伏笔缓缓收束，并最终为玩家带来一个个基于玩家选择和主人公性格的结局，实属不易。

游戏的主题其实是失去。游戏引入了自动存档机制，这就使得每一个选择都无法被反悔，玩家做出的选择完全出于自己对故事和人物的理解，而非字面意义上的“做出最佳选择”。游戏里没有哪一个选择是完全正确的，然而这些选择的结果很快就能反映在接下来的剧情中，并对最终结局产生影响。玩家在一个个的选择中塑造着属于自己的主人公：中期时为取得关键的调查信息，玩家会接到NPC的小任务。你可以跑跑腿去完成它们，也大可利用威胁的手段夺取讯息。这一切都取决于玩家的选择。在Tokyo Dark中，“选择”是切实有用的，而经过这些选择所塑造出的主角，也影响着故事的最终走向。

我认为好的文艺作品不需要“旁白”或是“引路人”。交代故事背景和设定的段落并非必要。相反，制作者更应该注意如何能让观众接受这个世界，让观众潜移默化的将自己代入到作品的主人公当中，在虚构世界营造出和现实世界相同的情感驱动。Tokyo Dark做到了这一点，主人公Ito塑造的十分真实。尽管身为主角，她也背负着自己的“恶”，作为调查员在一个个纠结的选择中挣扎。与主人公对立的是Reina，她不能被称为是反派，更多程度上，Reina是主角心中悲伤和遗憾的倒影。

总而言之，Tokyo Dark是一款完成度极高的AVG佳作，[spoiler] 建议喜欢Life is Strange 和 Cyberpunk Bartender的玩家都试一试这款游戏，我相信Tokyo Dark也能给你们带来同样的惊喜[/spoiler]

34898094.review:
Looking back to when I was first introduced to computer gaming, I distincly remember the classic Point-n-Click adventure game 'Return to Zork'. I guess that began my interest in Video Games, especially as a story telling media.

So when an email hit my inbox from SquareEnix Collective about a Western point-n-click adventure twist to the Japanese visual novel genre my interest was immediatly caught.
Then, after fully reading the email, I was to learn it was going to be a narrative driven psycological thriller.
Well that had me throwing my wallet at the screen yelling "Take my MONEY!", and once the opportunity to become a 'Backer' in the development of Tokyo Dark via Kickstarter, I jumped in with both feet.

Follwing the development of the game has been quite a trip. Monthly updates from the development team. Coupled with Beta build downloads for backers (Along with demo's available at SquareEnix's booth at San Diego Comic Con 2016) the ability to get 'hands on' during some of the early stages was only whetting my appetite for what was shaping up to a be a Point-n-Click Psycological Thriller Game I'd longed for.

With other games media quoting games like 'Life Is Strange' for gameplay and story telling from psychological thriller movies like 'Se7en', who am I to argue, I totally agree. 

Players manage Detective Ito's Sanity, Professionalisim, Investigation, and Neurosis (SPIN) through your decisions, and interactions with the other characters and the environment.
However, be forewarned, there is an Auto Save function meaning you have to 'Live' with the consequence of your actions. No going back to 'fix' a mistake, you're taking ownership of that choice. You either keep going, or start again from the beginning... and why would you go back to the beginning? You should keep going, see how deep that rabbit hole is, Alice.. Sorry Ito, and reach the conclusion.

There's 11 different endings in Tokyo Dark, and a lot of choices to be made getting there. So you're going to get plenty of re-playability in this title. I like that very much. There's a few too many AAA Titles out there that are far too singular with their story severly limiting the ability to 'go back' and try something different.

Do I think I'm going to get my moneys worth from my pledge 2 years ago? Yes, no hesitation. Hell I'll buy it again if I need to (Also some people I know may get given copies by me because I want them to play it)

Is it worth what they're asking (Price wise) here on Steam? Absolutly 100%

Tl/Dr:
Want a Point-n-Click Psycological Thriller set in Tokyo? If yes. Then buy Tokyo Dark by Cherrymochi

34896521.review:
Not much to say, the story is quite dark and intriguing in a way since it's a mystery game and all. Art is pretty good and there are some short video cinematics that are good quality by my standards.

The music does well in setting the creepy atmosphere though it's very loud and you'll have to lower the volume of the entire game if you don't want to blow your eardrums.

Disappointed that there were no voice lines other than a few grunts or phrases at the beginning of each dialogue, really felt lacking when they've got short animations yet no voice overs.

There are multiple endings that are based on your choices in the game, those choices also affect your Stress, Professionalism, Investigation, and Neurosis stats, and endings or choices may be altered depending on those stats.

All in all as a person that isn't very invested in the visual novel genre, the plot was interesting enough to keep me hooked. I'd definitely recommend it to anybody that shows interest in anime styled games and dark plots.

34896212.review:
Well, keep in mind I don't like horror and paranormal-related stuff and I've always been reluctant about point'n'click games. Tokyo Dark just appealed me out of nowhere, resulting me to give it a try even if I don't like the genre. But, it was so much more surprising that I would ever imagine.

Pros.
► Graphism, artworks are pretty clean while some levels are really welldone. The promoted cutscence made by that one studio looks fine but no need to bet on in neither. UI is pretty clean too.
► Audio, pretty great OST for an indie game and overall sound effects work great in installing the game's ambiance.
► Storyline, I've really hooked the storyline. Despite all the psycological horror theme, I've really enjoyed every bit of it. From detective business, to police HQ moment, to help people out and everything after that. Well built stroy with a good amout of definitive choices and momentum changing choices. 
► Characters design, the main grills characters (Itō -you- and Reina), especially Itō-waifu, own a pretty unique and well-created design. However Tanaka (your partner) falls a bit into a perfect, caring and altruistic hasbundo cliché 
► Deep ambiance, Tokyo Dark has no trouble to quickly create its own ambiance leading to insanity moments, crutial decision-making momentum and sometimes a more relaxed pace.
► Optimisation, runs smoothly without any trouble.
► SPIN system, nice touch to the game leading advanced character design.
► Visual novel and point'n'click hybird, well it is an interesting hybrid to be honest, having the freedom of point'n'click and the story-telling of a visual novel.
► Endings, this game own 11 different endings resulting of your choices plus 6 secondary endings linked to background characters which is pretty impressive tbh. About the ending I've chose (spoilers mah bois), [spoiler] after a rough start of doing everthing I could to help Itō leading to horribles consequences, after all the efforts of getting back on tracks thinking if I couldn't help myself I could help the others, during the final showdown between Itō and Reina, the game really gave the feels I've haven't done this much to help someone that ruined the character's life. The "Alone Toghter" ending, which is the first I chose was so powerful, well written, so satisfying and, oh boi, those feels. Those damn feels [/spoiler].

Neutrals.
► User Interface hitboxes, even if I have said the UI looks good, it unfortunately, sometimes, has bugged hitboxes, leading to pick the wrong button. Also, on some startup, the location info seems bugged leading to everyplace is called "<LOCATION>" or something like that.
► Game design new trends, like placing a puzzle with lights in the middle of a chase or put longass but interesting stories when approching the end. It's not a bad point because it keeps us on track with the game, it's just a little underwhelming, which, I think, was the point.

Cons.
► Unnecessary "jumpscares", it's not proper jumpscares hopefully but I got startled every single time from the beginning to the moment you have to pack things in your office (because I don't found any of them later) leading me to be really tense up to the end. Shoutout to the flashing mask in a deep dialogue in the sewer tho.
► Resolutions settings, there is N O N E.
► Dialogue interface that rarely mixes the person that speaks or rarely forget to add your interlocutor sprite.
► Dialogue interface hiding UI and other gamebreaking bugs, while the previous cons doesn't really affect the game, those will make you restart a new game  because they lead to corrupted savegame files, as far from what I heard. For exemple,  [spoiler] the pills scence have the dialogue interface bugged, so you must try to click the doorknob in blurry mess if you want to got to another place which will creat a new clean savefile [/spoiler]. Hopefully the devs, that have acknowledged it, are working on it.

TL;DR.
If you're startled at almost anything I still will recommend you Tokyo Dark with all my heart due to his great storyline, possibilities, great detective aspect, uniqueness and non horror cliché game design. And because of Itō, of course. If devs read this, I want to say thanks a lot, I haven't felt anything in months (I know most of the others players wouldn't felt as much as I did playing this, but I have been personnaly hit by this game).

94/100

34891938.review:
Tokyo Dark это пример того, какими могуть быть игры, если разработчики вкладывают в них всю свою любовь к их работе.
По жанровой принадлежности Tokyo Dark представляет из себя нуарный Point&Click с элементами психологического хоррора. Геймплейно же это скорее похоже на новеллу с возможностью выбора и тотальной нелинейностью. Игра действительно адаптируется под действия игрока, все, что вы когда либо сделали вам вернется. 
Теперь о самом геймплее: он представляет собой диалоги ,  с возможностью выбора как я уже говорил, исследование локаций, коих тут довольно много и все они выполнены очень стильно и атмосферно, и в конце концов небольшие загадки, которых в игре довольно мало, но это отнюдь не делает ее хуже. Отдельного упоминания стоит система SPIN ( это  4 показателя: вменяемость, расследование, профессионализм и нервозность) , на которую и влияют все действия протагонистки, а система в свою очередь влияет на сюжет.
Теперь о сюжете: Это одна из лучших и продуманных историй, которая мне встречалась в данном жанре игр. По нраву она придется не всем, или может кто-то восе ее не поймет... Это уже дело каждого. Начинается все очень просто, мы- детектив Аями Ито, которая отправляется на поиски своего напарника (он же еще и парень Ито) и череда событий сталкивает нас лицом к лицу со старинным культом, тайны которого нам предстоит разгадать и спасти попутно несколько людей. Концовок в игре около 13.
Что еще хотелось бы отметить так это звуковое сопровождение, которое здесь оформлено прекрасно. 
Итог: Это хорошая, качествення Point&Click новелла, которая заставит вас делать порою трудные выборы и даже сможет немного ужаснуть вас. Любители детективов с элементами мистики точно оценят.
9/10

34884148.review:
鎌倉のインディーズスタジオが開発したビジュアルノベルっぽいホラーアドベンチャーです。
主人公の伊藤刑事の相棒が行方不明になり、その手掛かりを見つけて現場に踏み込んだものの…といったあらすじになります。
ストーリーはオカルト色の強いものですが、全体的に人間の心の闇が表現されており、じわりとした恐怖が感じられました。

システム的にはオーソドックスなポイント＆クリック形式で進めていくもので、調べられる場所は画面内に表示されますので、詰まったりはしづらいです。
謎解きらしい謎解きもほとんどありませんが、主人公の取った行動によってパラメーターが変化するのが一つの特色でしょう。
このパラメーターはS.P.I.N値と呼ばれており、( Sanity 正気値、Professionalism プロフェッショナル値、Investigation 探索値、Neurosis ノイローゼ値)の略です。
現実とは思えないような現象に遭遇したらSAN値が下がるとか、刑事として相応しくない行動（勤務中に酒を飲むなど）をしたらプロ値が下がるとかいう感じになります。
下がりすぎるとバッドエンドになるのでうまく調整していく必要があります。

もう一つの特色として、ゲーム中に遭遇する問題の解決策が複数用意されています。
例えば相手から情報を引き出したいとして、相手の要求に応えて何かしてあげてもいいし、ぶん殴って無理やり聞き出してもOKといった形です。
正攻法で行くか、乱暴なやり方で行くかくらいのパターンが多いですが、ここまで力技で行くかという選択肢の新鮮さはありました。

ビジュアル的には豪華で、少人数のインディーズスタジオが開発したとは思えないほどです。
イベント時の絵も豊富ですし、アニメーションもあり、とても満足しました。キャラもかわいらしいです。
また、日本語ローカライズもしっかりとされており、小説家を起用しただけあってテキストの質は高かったです。

気になった点としては細かいバグがちらほら見られたことです。
セリフウィンドウの位置ずれがあったり、調べられないのにカーソルが表示されたりといった感じです。
もし発生したら画面を切り替えるか、いったんメインメニューに戻る必要があります。

細かい粗はあれど、開発者の熱意が感じられる出来の良いホラーADVですので、是非おすすめします。

34880628.review:
Tokyo Dark is categorized as an Aventure/Visual Novel hybrid but in actuality it's mostly point & click and text without much adventure. There's one very simple puzzle in the entire game and the rest of the gameplay consists of going back and forth talking to people, along with interacting with or picking up a few objects along the way. This doesn't necessarily make the game bad, but it doesn't require much thought to progress in the game, so if you buy the game don't put your thinking cap on cuz you likely won't need it.

With as much text this game has, you think it would appeal more to fans of visual novels, but I can't recommend it for that. The story and character interactions are ultimately dull and the quality is on par with just about any generic horror movie. I think it could've been more enjoyable if it had full voice acting, which I was surprised to find that it didn't have. There was a voice acting stretch goal for the Kickstarter which was met, plus $225k canadian dollars were pledged for the project in total, so they definitely should have had the funding for full voice acting. $225k for this game alone is overkill considering the lack of quality put into it, which leaves me wondering what most of that money went into. As the game is now, it barely has any voice overs, and they're all for Detective Ito. The lack of voice acting was a major disappointment for me, being a Kickstarter backer.

The "Beautifully animated sequences produced by Graphinica" are quite short and forgettable. I appreciate that there are animated scenes in the game, but it doesn't add much substance to it. It's kind of like a "special feature" added to lure people in, but when you try the product you hardly even notice it. The soundtrack is well made fitting the horror vibe well enough, and the art quality is decent. I would have preferred a better UI design. The settings menu is lazily designed, not letting you adjust voice/sound effects/music volumes individually is slightly annoying.

The S.P.I.N (Sanity, Professionalism, Investigation, Neurosis) system seems like it would have more consequences in concept, but it ends up being more of a gimmick. It's required to manipulate your SPIN stats to get a few endings so there is some use to it, though I've gotten 6 endings (including the true ending) without paying much attention to the choices I've made. Despite what the store page says, I don't remember encountering any different character dialogue/reactions based on what my stats were. I can't speak for all of the endings, but the endings that I played through were uninteresting and predictable. Nothing shocked me, no twists or anything, just boring. The ending branches aren't sophisticated so you can probably get all of them in 2 or 3 complete playthroughs (a lot of them branch at 2 choices near the end of the game) using a guide without too much hassle. New Game+ is unlocked after your first playthrough which enables you to skip some previously read text (but not all) and unlocks save slots making endings more accessible.

Each ending route will take about 6 hours to finish initially, with each additional route being much shorter once you skip text in NG+. At a total of 11 endings, there is a fair amount of replayability, but not much content. IMO the endings don't warrant multiple playthroughs, they weren't interesting enough to me and they artificially inflate the small amount of content available. I'd expect more quality at $18 than this, especially after the amount of funding they got from Kickstarter. If you're dead set on buying it I suggest waiting for it to go on sale for $5 or an eventual Humble bundle (which will likely happen since it's published by Square Enix).

34878634.review: It seems like some of what was hinted at in the Kickstarter fell by the wayside (it seemed like they had aimed for more interactivity, but maybe they couldn't quite figure out how to work it out well enough), but the game still holds up well because of the solid story, decent storyline choices, and the great atmosphere (which is why I backed it in the first place).  Replayability is rather high if  you want to experience different events and endings. I'm not a big fan of point-and-click or visual novel games, but there was always something intriguing about this game regardless. And it's the story. If you want a good story, well... here you go.

34875948.review:
Yes... sort of. 

This is a tricky one. I feel there is a good game "in there somewhere" and what is presented is compelling enough to drag someone to one of its [spoiler]multiple endings[/spoiler] at least once... however--

There's a laundry list of issues that prevent this from being a total recommendation:

[list]
[*]A spartan, mostly-functional, often-frustrating UI
[*]A nearly invisble mouse cursor that will distract you from immersion more than once
[*]An inconsistent art style between characters, environments, music, etc.
[*]No real explanation or demonstration of the SPIN system (just lets you know "It's a thing")
[*]Clunky play control style that will leave you feeling disconnected from the protagonist
[*]Really thin content with lots of interesting setups that don't go anywhere and keep you on the main-story track
[/list]

So yeah, do I think it's a good game? Yes... ish.

Would I recommend it? Sure... kinda... with some warnings.

I feel like there's a better game in the ideas and concepts that this game touches on, both mechanically and story-wise. It leans hard on some fairly trope-y motivations for its characters and can't seem to really figure out what its antagonist's motivations are ([spoiler]There are a couple very different, unrelated reasons for the antagonist to "hate" that seem disconnected and unexplored; it's as if two writers had two different backstories outlined and they just included them both[/spoiler]).  You don't really get to spend a lot of "time" with your characters, as the story comes at you fast when it's story time, and is non-existent when it's side-quest time. 

Oh yeah, this game has weird, non-sequitur side-quests. 

The game at its best is dour, dark, unrelenting, but then seems to drag in some incongruous light-heartedness, and instead of feeling like "respite" (which seems like the intention) it just feels like you're playing a different story for a few minutes every now and then. 

Again, it's frustrating, there's the core of something brilliant here, but I feel like something along the way, (time, budget, writing ability, etc.) cut itself off at the knees. 

I'm not giving it a "no" because it's by no means a "bad" game... but it's just a shadow if what it could have been.
